Question: Does every page need an <h1>?

Answer.Main: Only at the AAA level.
Answer.Details: However, if there are any headings, they need to be descriptive and they each need to be at an appropriate level, otherwise it's 2.4.6 - Headings and Labels (Level AA) and 1.3.1 - Info and Relationships (Level A) respectively.

Failure: No. However some organizations may have it as an internal standard. Example: the Canada.ca Content Style Guide

Question: Can heading levels be skipped?

Answer.Main: Yes, but it's bad practice
Answer.Details:
Heading levels should create a hierarchical structure of the document. Logically, therefore heading levels should not be skipped. The reason that WCAG allows levels to be skipped is:

Currently correct hierarchical nesting is a best practise but not a WCAG failure. That was carefully negotiated during the creation of WCAG 2.0 by companies that have content coming from many sources who could not guarantee hierarchy, and at the time many screen reader users just press H. H, H to move through headings, or pulled up a list of headings without specific concern about the level.

David MacDonald's comment on H42 missing appropriate hierarchical level condition · Issue #655 · w3c/wcag.

In summary: the reason WCAG doesn't require non-skipped headings is because of exceptional circumstances. Skipped headings should only be skipped when it cannot be avoided.

See Heading off confusion: When do headings fail WCAG? - TPGi for more information.

SuccessCriteria:
• 2.4.6 Headings and Labels
  • 1.3.1 - Info and Relationships

Question: Can there be more than 1 <h1> on a page?

Answer.Main: Yes, technically, but it's not advisable.
Answer.Details: WCAG doesn't explicitly say there can only be 1 <h1>. However, having more than 1 <h1> can create an illogical page hierarchy. The vast majority of pages that use headings (properly) use <h1>s to mimic the <title> of the page. As per 2.4.6 Headings and Labels, the <h1> should describe the content of the section it heads, ie: the main content. Having multiple <h1>s creates an illogical and confusing hierarchy.See Heading off confusion: When do headings fail WCAG? - TPGi for more information.

SuccessCriteria:
• 2.4.6 Headings and Labels
  • 1.3.1 - Info and Relationships
Failure: No, but some organizations may have it as an internal standard. Example: the Canada.ca Content Style Guide.

Question: Is the use of autocomplete='' obligatory on input fields?

Answer.Main:
For input fields that are repetitive across the web (email, password, birthday, etc), yes. However, it can be set to "off" on those elements if desired.

If the input field is app or site specific, such as "Enter your PUI code here", the field doesn't require the autocomplete attribute. However, it still is recommended.

Question: Does a page need to validate HTML?

Answer.Main: Yes. The HTML of a page or an app needs to validate to make sure that the code is not depricated, so that we can be sure that assistive technologies interpretate the HTML code correctly. Make sure to always validate after JavaScript.

Question: Does CSS need to validate on pages?

Answer.Main: No. CSS won't interfere with the way assistive technologies understand content on a page. However, it is still encourage to do so.

Question: A non-visible element gets the focus - is this a fail?

Answer.Main:
If the invisible element gets on focus in the middle of an operation (tabing through elements in a menu for example): Yes. The focus order needs to be constent and predictable while tabbing through a section where the tab order is important and might interfere with the understanding of the section.

However, if this occure outside or between two sections and it doesn't break the meaning of the content or the expected behaviour, no this is not an issue althought it is still not encouraged.

Question: Do <input> fields' placeholders need to pass colour contrast ratio?

Answer.Main:
If the placeholder text is all there is as instructions for the input field before typing in (such as "Write email here"), yes. However if there is a static / permanent <label> with the same instructions as text and it's linked to the input field via ID, no - it's optional. However, it is still recommended.

**Note: If the placeholder text is all there is as instructions before typing in AND as typing in, this is a 3.3.2 - Labels or Instructions (Level A) fail.

Question: Do disabled elements (<input>, <button>, etc) need to pass minimum contrast ratio?

Answer.Main: If an element is disabled, by definition it means that it's not necessary in the current context. However, the element needs to have a good reason to be disabled, or it could fail another WCAG criterion. For example, a disabled submit button in a form that only enables when the form is filled would be a fail (failing 3.3.1 - Error Identification).
Answer.Details:
To make things simple, all default HTML elements styling natively pass contrast ratio. This means if you didn't change the colour or background colour of a <button> (for example), you don't have to worry about it passing colour contrast.

Exception: placeholders on an <input> field that acts as the only intstructions available to users (which would fail 3.3.2 - Labels or Instructions itself: placeholders must not be used as the only way to provide instructions).

Question: What is the minimum colour contrast ratio for text & UI elements?

Answer.Main:
Text and images of text (text in an image) must have a minimum contrast radio of 4:5:1.

Exceptions:

  • Large text (font size of 18pt or 14pt in bold) require a minimum contrast radio of 3:1;
  • Text or images of text that are part of an inactive user interface component, that are pure decoration, that are not visible to anyone, or that are part of a picture that contains significant other visual content, have no contrast requirement;
  • Text that is part of a logo or brand name has no contrast requirement.

Question: Do new password requirements need to be displayed when filling a "create account" or "change password" type of form?

Answer.Main:
Yes.

For every <input> field, instructions or labels need to specify to users exactly what type of data is expected as input, especially if there's a specific format or rule. This includes passwords.

Question: Login error not announced by screen reader - is this a fail?

Answer.Main: Yes. If necessary, an aria-live attribute should be used on the error message to announce its presence to screen readers.

Question: The content of a page or a section can only be scrolled with a mouse - is this a fail?

Answer.Main: Yes. A web page must not rely on using a mouse to access all of its content.
Answer.Details: In the case of something like a map, the site must ensure that users can use their keyboards to use it too.

Question: The alt="" attribute of an <img> is empty - is this a fail?

Answer.Main:
If the image is decorative, it's ok and actually expected of it to be empty. As long as the alt attribute is there.
If however the image is necessary to understand the content nearby, the alt="" attribute must not be empty and must represent the image in text form.

Question: An <img> lacks an alt="" attribute - is this a fail?

Answer.Main: Yes. An image must always have an alt="" attribute.
Answer.Details: However, the alt="" attribute can be empty if the image is decorative and is not necessary to understand the content of the page.

Question: Is using aria attributes failing WCAG?

Answer.Main:
No.
The purpose of using aria is to enhance the accessibility of a site that uses custom HTML widgets.
Answer.Details: However, it is strongly advised to avoid using aria as much as possible, and to use the default HTML tags and widgets to ensure a maximum of accessibility compatibility.

Question: If a site has no log out time (you stay logged in as long as you don't logout yourself), does it fail WCAG?

Answer.Main: No. There is no accessibility concern.

Question: What is considered as "Large text" in WCAG?

Answer.Main: Text that is 18pt (24px) or higher.

Question: Can an <input> be child of a <label>?

Answer.Main:
Yes.
This won't be flagged as an HTML issue by the W3C Validator and it won't change the behaviour of assistive technologies.

Question: An accessibility issue is only occuring with one specific setup (browser, screen reader + browser, OS, etc) - is this a fail?

Answer.Main:
No.
If the accessibility issue only occurs using a specific browser, screen reader, operating system, etc. That falls in the category of a software bug coming from those technologies, not a problem in the webpage's code.
